item.title: Multi-dimensional impacts of the family planning policy: deep transformations from social structure to economic and political changes
item.description:
China’s population control policies, while limiting growth and curbing family-style development, have disrupted traditional social structures, suppressed the expansion of family-owned businesses and political dynasty power, presenting a unique case compared to Korean conglomerates and Indian family monopolies. Now that birth restrictions are being relaxed, despite facing challenges such as low fertility rates, it’s crucial to be wary of new monopoly risks, requiring multiple parties to seek balance.

One: The Tension Between Population Control and Family-Style Development

The family planning policy, implemented in China for nearly forty years as a basic national strategy, has achieved significant direct results. Data shows that from 1978 to 2007, China’s natural population growth rate fell from 12‰ to 5.2‰, resulting in a reduction of over 40 million people, and the country’s share of the world’s population decreased from 22.2% to 20.1%. This sharp deceleration in population growth profoundly reshaped China’s social family structure. Taking family-owned enterprises as an example, after the implementation of the family planning policy, the number of children born by business owners declined significantly: before the policy, the proportion of those having three or more children was 40.63%, and after the policy it plummeted to 18.46%, the proportion of single sons born increased from 6.25% to 32.31%. This structural change directly reduced the range of potential internal successors for family-owned enterprises, objectively suppressing their generational expansion capabilities.

One: The Tension Between Population Control and Familial Development

Comparing Korea and India reveals significant differences. While Korea did not implement strict birth control measures, fertility rates have remained low for a long time (0.7 in 2023), the chaebols still firmly control the nation’s economic lifeline through cross-shareholdings and tax avoidance strategies like inheritance taxes. The top five chaebols account for over 50% of Korea’s GDP, with Samsung Group alone contributing 20%. India presents a contrasting picture: 79% of its economic output is contributed by family-owned businesses, with six major conglomerates controlling key sectors such as telecommunications and steel, and the top 20 enterprises earning 80% of national corporate profits. The core difference lies in the fact that China’s birth control policies limited family sizes, thereby weakening the human resources base for chaebol expansion at its source. Due to different policy environments, familial power has continued to penetrate economic sectors in Korea and India.

II. Monopoly Restraint and Social Structural Transformation

The impact of the family planning policy on the economic sector is particularly evident in its suppression of monopolistic phenomena. Due to declining birth rates, Chinese family businesses have struggled to form conglomerates similar to those in South Korea and Japan. Taking South Korea as an example, chaebols maintained their control through “circular capital” investments, with the Samsung family holding only 2% of the group’s shares while controlling the entire operation through complex equity structures. Conversely, in China, family businesses following the family planning policy generally faced difficulties in “passing down the business to one’s children,” often necessitating the introduction of professional managers or implementing equity diversification reforms. According to a湃新闻 (Papare News) study, the proportion of female successors in family-owned enterprises after the family planning policy increased from 13.85% to 34.21%, and the educational attainment of these successors significantly improved, with the percentage of undergraduates rising from 43.75% to 98.46%. This transition, while not completely eliminating family control, significantly reduced the possibility of a single family monopolizing the market.

At the social structure level, the population planning policy accelerated the breakdown of traditional family core patterns. China’s average household size decreased from 4.41 people/household in 1982 to 2.62 people/household in 2020, with smaller families weakening the family’s functions in areas such as economics, education, and social support. In contrast, India maintains an average family size of around 4 people, with the caste system deeply intertwined with family power, leading to low social mobility. China’s transformation of its family structure created space for individualism; in 2023, China had 240 million single adult citizens, and a trend of “one-person economy” emerged in the consumer market, further diminishing the influence of family economies.

Three. Decentralization of Power in the Political Sphere

The impact of the family planning policy on the political landscape has been profound. Traditionally, family power structures had infiltrated grassroots politics through bloodlines and kinship relationships. For example, in Henan’s Xinye County, 161 political families almost controlled all government departments, with 20% of deputy-level and above officials belonging to “officer’s children.” However, after the implementation of the family planning policy, shrinking family sizes limited the expansion of family networks. Research from Peking University showed that the number of offspring of officials decreased following family planning, and the complexity of family political networks significantly declined. Furthermore, the policy-driven increase in education (the average years of education increased from 5.2 years in 1982 to 10.9 years in 2023) promoted social mobility, weakening the monopoly of family power over political resources. Comparing Korea and India, the deep entanglement between Korean conglomerates (like Samsung Group executives and government corruption) and India’s caste-based hereditary political lineage highlights the uniqueness of Chinese policy. China, through its population control policies, objectively reduced the possibility of power succession. While familial phenomena still exist within county-level politics, the overall trend is towards a decentralization of power structures. During the 2025 National People’s Congress (NPC) session, an NPC delegate proposed renaming “The Population and Family Planning Law” to “The Population and Reproduction Law,” fully opening up birth limits – a move that could further influence the evolution of future political ecosystems.

Four. Challenges and Opportunities Following Policy Adjustments

The implementation of the 2016 comprehensive two-child policy and the 2021 three-child policy marked a significant shift in China’s birth policies. However, the policy effects were limited: births in 2022 totaled only 1.18, far below the replacement level (2.1). The relaxation of birth restrictions had a dual impact on family-owned businesses: on one hand, some entrepreneurs may strengthen family succession capabilities through multiple children, such as Zong Qinghui, the daughter of Wahaha Group founder Zong Qunhui, who took over as the sole heir; on the other hand, high childcare costs (the average cost of raising a child to 18 years old in first-tier cities reaches 1 million yuan) and declining fertility intentions among professional women limited the expansion of family size.

In the economic sphere, relaxing birth restrictions may give rise to new monopoly forms. The three-child policy has accelerated the concentration of the infant care and childcare industries, with the market size for infant care expected to reach 1621 in 2025. - 300 million yuan

  • Leading enterprises are utilizing mergers and acquisitions to integrate smaller manufacturers, resulting in a CR5 market concentration exceeding 55%. This increase in concentration may bring about efficiency gains, but it also warrants vigilance against new monopoly risks. The government needs to strike a balance between encouraging childbirth and preventing market consolidation, such as strengthening regulation through antitrust laws while providing childcare subsidies (e.g., Hangzhou’s three-child families receiving RMB 3,000 per month in milk powder allowances) to alleviate household burdens.

  • In the political sphere, relaxing birth restrictions could have subtle impacts on family power structures. While it is unlikely to restore traditional family political networks in the short term, over the long term, larger families may form new influence within grassroots politics. Therefore, refining personnel selection mechanisms and strengthening oversight (such as establishing a nepotism avoidance system for officials) remains crucial in preventing hereditary power.

Five. International Mirroring and Future Outlook

The experiences of South Korea and India demonstrate that the ebb and flow of family power is closely linked to policy orientations. South Korea achieved economic takeoff by supporting conglomerates, but at the cost of social inequality; India’s failure to implement effective policies to curb family monopolies has exacerbated wealth disparity. China’s population control policy effectively controlled population growth while objectively suppressing the expansion of family power, but it also resulted in accelerated aging and labor shortages.

Looking ahead, China needs to find a new balance between population policy and socio-economic development. On one hand, through fertility support policies (such as extending maternity leave and building universal childcare institutions) increase birth rates; on the other hand, strengthen antitrust enforcement to prevent family businesses from forming new monopolies through capital operations. In the political sphere, further progress must be made in grassroots democratic construction, with enhanced oversight mechanisms to ensure transparency in governance. Ultimately, the family planning policy served as a key driver of social transformation in China; its impact extended far beyond population issues. It reshaped family structures, economic models, and the political landscape, providing a path for China to avoid falling into the trap of family monopolies like those seen in Korea and India. With the adjustment of the policy, balancing efficiency with equity, freedom with order, will remain a long-term challenge facing China in its new demographic context.

item.title: Trade war abruptly called a pause
item.description:
The evolution of trade war tariffs in 2025 presented a “escalation – counter-repressive measures – negotiations” cycle, with the US-China rivalry shifting from tariff confrontation to competition over rules. Despite short-term easing that alleviated market pressure, long-term uncertainty persists, and it’s crucial to monitor WTO rulings, supply chain adjustments, and geopolitical shifts’ sustained impact on the global economy.

People don’t earn money beyond their own perception; the stock market crash triggered by the launch of the trade war this year has largely recovered, but countless retail investors have been buried along the way.

2025 Trade War Tariff Timeline Overview

Here’s a timeline of the trade war tariff events, combining key events involving the US and China, and other countries, illustrating the dynamic evolution of tariff policies:

I. April 2025: Comprehensive Upgrade and Countermeasures on Tariffs

  1. U.S. Tariff Measures Against China
    • April 2nd: The Trump administration signed Executive Order No. 14257, announcing the imposition of a 34% “retaliatory tariff” on goods shipped from China to the U.S., covering products originating in Hong Kong and Macao.
    • April 8th: The United States further increased the “retaliatory tariff” rate on Chinese goods from 34% to 84%, and signed Executive Orders No. 14259 and 14266, imposing tariffs on additional products.
    • April 10th: The White House amended the executive order, increasing the total tariff amount against China to 145%, and raising the tariff rate on small packages (such as goods priced below $800 from 90% to 120%).
  • China’s Countermeasures
    • April 4th: China announced the imposition of a 34% tariff on all goods originating in the United States, covering sectors such as agricultural products, automobiles, and energy. - April 10th: China will retaliate against the tariff rate increase from 34% to 84%, in sync with the US side.
    • April 12th: China cancels the additional tariffs imposed on U.S. goods by 91% (corresponding to part of the cancellation by the US side) and suspends the implementation of 24% tariffs for 90 days, retaining 10%.

I. April 2025: Comprehensive Tariff Upgrade and Countermeasures

  • Tariff Games Involving Other Countries
    • US-Canada Trade War: The United States imposes 25% tariffs on Canadian steel and aluminum products, and Canada retaliates by taxing goods worth $298 billion from the US, as well as filing a WTO dispute.
    • EU & Japan: The EU imposes maximum 25% tariffs on US goods, while Japan expresses concern over auto tariffs imposed by the US, calling the trade war “harming both sides.”

II. May 2025: Geneva Talks and Tariff De-escalation

  1. US-China High-Level Trade Talks
    • May 10-11: The US and China held a 16-hour meeting in Geneva, Switzerland, reaching the “Joint Statement on the US-China Economic Talks.”
    • May 12: Both sides announced a suspension of some tariffs:
      • The United States paused its 24% tariff on Chinese goods (90 days), retaining 10%, and rescinded the additional tariffs imposed on April 8th and 9th.
      • China simultaneously suspended its 24% retaliatory tariffs, retaining 10%, and lifted non-tariff measures.
    • Establishment of a Consultation Mechanism: Both sides agreed to hold regular trade consultations in China, the United States, or a third country, focusing on tariff reduction and rulemaking.
  • Economic Impact and Policy Adjustments
    • US Domestic Pressure: High tariffs led to the closure of small and medium-sized enterprises (such as Amazon sellers forced to close due to tariff surges) and rising inflation expectations (core PCE is expected to rise to 3…

III. Other Key Events and Long-Term Impacts

  1. WTO and Multilateral Responses

    • Canada and China both lodged WTO disputes against the U.S. steel and aluminum tariffs and “retaliatory tariffs,” alleging violations of non-discrimination principles.
    • WTO Director-General Azevedo warned that U.S. tariffs could cause a 1% contraction in global trade volumes by 2025, exacerbating difficulties for developing countries.

  2. Exemption Lists and Industry Impacts

    • U.S. Excluded Goods: A 37-page list covering strategic materials such as rare earths, graphite, and medical CT balls exposed supply chain vulnerabilities.
    • Auto Tariffs: The U.S. imposed 25% tariffs on imported automobiles, leading to an estimated 2% decline in global auto production and a 9% reduction in North American output.

  3. Political and Strategic Maneuvering

    • The Trump administration attempted to reshape the international trade order through “retaliatory tariffs,” but was criticized as unilateral bullying, triggering backlash from allies (such as the EU and Japan).

Four. Timeline Summary

Four. Timeline Summary

Four. Timeline Summary

Four. Timeline Summary

Five. Trends and Challenges

  • Short-Term Relief and Long-Term Competition: The suspension of US-China tariffs sent positive signals, but structural issues (such as high technology and energy) remain, with mid-term elections or policy continuity impacting the outlook.
  • Global Supply Chain Restructuring: Companies are accelerating adjustments to their supply chains, with Mexico and Southeast Asia benefiting from “nearshoring,” but rising costs may dampen recovery.
  • Multilateral Mechanism Dilemmas: The WTO dispute resolution mechanism is constrained, regional trade agreements (such as the US-UK agreement) are emerging as alternative options, but this could exacerbate fragmentation.

item.title: The “Tiangong” (Heavenly Palace) incident in medical education and the Butterfly Effect of Dong Xi Ying’s case
item.description:
The Beijing Children’s Hospital “4+4” project (4 years non-medical bachelor’s + 4 years medical doctorate) focuses on interdisciplinary elite cultivation. The exposure of Dong Xi Ying’s case in 2025 revealed her use of family background (medical/scientific research lineage) to gain entry into the program, raising concerns about the ambiguity of her qualifications, allegations of plagiarism in her dissertation, and exposing contradictions between its elite recruitment model and fairness, as well as ongoing debates regarding shortened study durations and internship training.

Prompts

Writing a blog: Harmony 4+4 Origin and Development, Core: A Corner of Tian Gong, Seen by Mortals, Dong Xiaojie’s Family Background, Normal Medical Doctor Cannot Graduate in Eight Years, Dong Xiaojie’s Family Background & Educational Background

Harmony 4+4: Deconstructing Medical Education’s “Tian Gong”

The “4+4” project at the Beijing Union Medical College, since its launch in 2018, has been viewed as China’s “Tian Gong” – or celestial palace – in medical education. This project, designed to mimic the American medical education system, adopted the philosophy of “cultivating multidisciplinary backgrounds, nurturing love for medicine, and attracting outstanding talents from across the nation.” It aimed to create a rift within traditional Chinese medical education by: replacing the traditional 5+3+3 (five-year bachelor’s degree + three-year master’s degree + three-year doctoral degree) model with a four-year non-medical undergraduate program plus a four-year medical doctorate training. This was intended to cultivate cross-disciplinary leadership talent in medicine.

This project’s “Tian Gong” attributes are reflected across three dimensions:

  1. Elite Recruitment: Early requirements stipulated that applicants must come from QS/Times/US News ranked top 50 universities or US News’s top 10 liberal arts colleges (such as Barnard College), later relaxed to the top 100, but still requiring a GPA of 3.6 or being within the top 30% of their class. Internationalization of Curriculum Pathways: Adopting an organ-system integration curriculum in the American style, PBL (Problem-Based Learning) methodology, students must complete core courses such as anatomy and pathology within 4 years, and participate in clinical internships.

  2. Controversy Regarding Export Quality: Despite a slightly lower pass rate for practitioners’ examinations (95.2%) compared to the traditional eight-year program (98.5%), graduates predominantly enter affiliated hospitals, and their career development shows no significant difference from traditional pathways.

Dong Xiying Incident: A “Celestial Realm” Crack Revealed by Ordinary Eyes

In April 2025, the extramarital affair involving Xiao Fei, a thoracic surgeon at the China-Japan Friendship Hospital, triggered scrutiny of the “4+4 Project” of the Traditional Chinese Medicine Hospital of Capital Medical University, commonly known as “Covelong 4+4.” The background of Dong Xiying, the key figure involved, sparked three major questions:

  1. Ambiguity Regarding Educational Background:
    • Dispute Over Undergraduate Institution: Dong Xiying claimed to have graduated from Columbia University, but she actually attended Barnard College (ranked 14th in US News & World Report for liberal arts colleges in 2025). Although the college met Covelong’s requirement of “top 20 liberal arts colleges,” her diploma simultaneously listed “Barnard College” and “Columbia University,” which could easily be misinterpreted as Columbia University’s main campus in the domestic recruitment market.
    • Dispute Over Professional Field: An economics undergraduate degree combined with a clinical medicine doctorate, while aligning with the 4+4 project’s positioning of “multi-disciplinary background,” has been questioned for lacking a foundation in pre-clinical medical courses.

Dong Xi Ying Incident: Peering Through the “Heavenly Palace” Crack – A Glimpse for Ordinary People

  • Unique Family Background:

    • Academic Resource Monopoly: Her father was the secretary of the China Metallurgical and Research Bureau Construction Institute, her mother was a deputy director of the North Medical University Engineering Technology Research Institute, and her grandfather was an academician in the field of medical imaging. Her paternal grandparents were doctoral supervisors (Doyens) at North Medical University in the field of materials. This “medicine + research + university” composite family background provided implicit resources such as recommendation letters (requiring recommendations from two biomedical associate professors) and research collaborations (such as North Medical University patents).
    • Career Path Leaps: She transitioned from cardiac surgery during residency to urology, with research spanning orthopedics, gastroenterology, radiology, and other fields. This was questioned as “paved road” due to the rapid changes in her career path.

  • Exaggerated Dispute Over Study Duration:

    • Reasonableness of Time Compression: Traditional medical doctorates require 11 years (5+3+3), while the 4+4 program compressed the time to 8 years. Despite Harmony emphasizing “curriculum integration” and “early clinical exposure,” some physicians pointed out that its clinical internship period (12 months) is still less than the traditional eight-year program (18 months), potentially impacting skill accumulation.

  • The Controversy Regarding CCT Reduction: Some CCT bases allowing 4+4 graduates to waive one year of CCT are being questioned for undermining industry fairness.

The Medical Education Quagmire Behind the Controversy

The Dong Xiying incident reflects deep contradictions within Chinese medical education:

  1. Conflict between Elitism and Equity:

    • The “application-assessment” system of the 4+4 program is essentially a transplantation of the American medical school model, but China lacks standardized exams like MCAT, relying instead on subjective evaluations such as recommendations and research experience, which are significantly influenced by family background.
    • Data shows that among graduates of the 4+4 program in 2023, 30% came from Qingbei Fuzhou (the top universities), and 25% from overseas prestigious schools. The influence of family background on applications is significant.

  2. The Reality of Curriculum Reform:

    • The Cost of Time Compression: 4+4 students produce significantly fewer research outputs (such as the number of publications) than traditional eight-year programs, and are accused of “prioritizing clinical work over research.”
    • Divergence in Industry Recognition: Three-tier hospitals prioritize the reputation of Covance (the name of the top university), while基层医院 (jīchéng yīyuàn - primary hospitals) maintain a cautious attitude towards the clinical abilities of 4+4 graduates. - The Confusion Surrounding the International Integration of Medical Education:
  • The US 4+4 model requires passing the MCAT exam and completing a 3-7 year residency, while China’s 4+4 programs have simplified the entry and residency stages, leading to “form resembling but not truly similar.”
  • Data from the Ministry of Education shows that in 2024, 4+4 programs accounted for less than 5% of national medical doctorate admissions, and their large-scale promotion still faces resistance.

Conclusion: Reconstructing the “Tiangong” Order of Medical Education

The controversy surrounding the CoHo 4+4 project fundamentally represents a clash between elite education and public expectations. When a corner of the “Tiangong” (Heavenly Palace) was glimpsed by mortals, it exposed not just isolated instances of flaws, but deeper contradictions within the entire medical education system. Future reforms must focus on three levels:

  1. Transparent Selection Mechanisms: Introduce standardized exams (such as a Chinese version of MCAT) to reduce the influence of subjective factors like letters of recommendation.
  2. Extend Clinical Training Cycle: Restore the clinical training cycle for 4+4 graduates to 3 years, ensuring that clinical competence is achieved.
  3. Strengthen Process Oversight: Establish an academic integrity review mechanism and conduct rigorous originality verification for interdisciplinary research.

Medical education’s “Tiangong” should not be a privilege reserved for a select few, but rather a true cradle for nurturing medical elites.

item.title: Wide Base Exponential Fixed Investment (also known as “Bullet Strategy”): Brokerage ETF, Heng Seng Tech Index
item.description:
I’ve always wanted to do things, like buying a suitable blue-chip stock and just letting it sit, waiting for it to drop so I could assess the situation before adding more, and selling when it rose. The result was that I never managed to do it.

Finding an appropriate blue-chip stock is troublesome; instead, choosing a broad market index ETF would suffice. My current plan is: a brokerage ETF and the Hong Kong Tech Index.

The kind of trading strategy described above has a professional term: “bottom fishing” (buying back when the price is falling).

As for what’s next, my plan is to choose a broad market index to thoroughly practice it – achieving an annualized return that outperforms regular savings account interest rates would be the goal.

Brokerage ETFs

A brokerage ETF is an Exchange Traded Fund (ETF) whose primary investment target is Chinese securities companies. It primarily invests in the listed stocks of Chinese securities companies in the stock market. Brokerage ETFs typically track a specific brokerage company index, such as the China Securities Brokerage Index.

I previously bought one, but it was at a peak and ultimately resulted in losses, so I liquidated my position. In the Chinese market, whenever there’s a bull run, brokerage companies are bound to rise – and by how much, depends on investor sentiment.

Hang Seng Tech Index

The Hang Seng Tech Index is an equity index launched by the Hong Kong Exchange, designed to reflect the overall performance of the technology industry in Hong Kong markets. The index includes major technology companies listed on the Hong Kong Stock Exchange, covering areas such as internet, e-commerce, cloud computing, and artificial intelligence.

  1. Weight Cap Mechanism: The Hang Seng Tech Index sets an 8% weight limit for individual stocks. For example, before the adjustment on March 2025, SMIC’s weighting exceeded 8%, but was subsequently passively reduced to comply with the limits.

  2. Constituent Stock Adjustments: On May 16, 2025, the Hang Seng Index Company announced that BYD ( 01211.HK ) will be included in the index and Shun Hing Assets ( 00772.HK ) will be excluded. The adjustment will take effect on June 6th. Therefore, as of today (May 20th), the constituent stocks are based on the pre-adjustment list, and BYD has not yet been included.

  3. Industry Distribution: Among the top ten constituent stocks, internet technology companies (such as Tencent, Alibaba, Meituan) dominate, with new energy vehicles (Xiaomi, Ideal) and semiconductors (SMIC) having significant weights, reflecting the index’s coverage of technology and the new economy. Data Timeliness: The primary differences in data from various sources stem from differing statistical time points. For example, data from March 2025 showed a combined top ten share of approximately 69.4%, while data from May 14th indicated 68.82%, reflecting the dynamic impact of market fluctuations on the weighting distribution.

Short Put Cover

The “Short Put Cover” strategy is an investment approach where investors, anticipating a stock price approaching its bottom as it continues to decline, actively buy in batches to reduce their cost basis and wait for future price recovery.

This method falls under the category of “short trading,” which involves counter-trend operations before the market has clearly found its bottom. Specifically, investors typically employ a “pyramidal” layering strategy – gradually increasing the purchase quantity as the stock price declines, thereby reducing the average cost basis of their holdings. For example, initially buying a certain number of shares, if the price continues to fall, the investor increases the purchase volume at a lower price, and so on.

Advantages:

  • Reduce Cost Basis: By purchasing in batches during the decline, you reduce the average cost basis of your holdings, creating conditions for future profits. - Strategic Positioning (Early Layout): Establishing positions before the market reverses, aiming to realize greater profits when the market rebounds.
  • Disadvantages:
    • High Risk: If stock prices continue to fall, it could lead to larger losses.
    • Capital Tie-up: Requires sufficient funds to continuously add to positions and may face a situation where capital is long-term blocked.

Relatively speaking, “right-side trading” involves buying after the market trend becomes clear and there are definite signs of an upward movement in stock prices, which carries lower risk but could miss out on some initial gains during a rebound. Therefore, investors should choose a strategy suitable for their risk tolerance, capital situation, and market judgment.

Valuation Theory

Valuation theory is a core concept in finance that aims to assess the intrinsic value of assets or companies, providing a basis for investment decisions. Through valuation, investors can determine whether the current market price of an asset is reasonable and develop appropriate investment strategies accordingly.

Key Valuation Methods:

  1. Discounted Cash Flow (DCF) Method: This method is based on the cash flows expected to be generated by an asset over its future period and discounts these cash flows to their present value using an appropriate discount rate. The DCF method emphasizes intrinsic value and is suitable for evaluating companies with stable and predictable earnings.
  2. Relative Valuation Method: This method assesses a company’s relative value by comparing valuation metrics such as Price-to-Earnings (P/E) ratio, Price-to-Book (P/B) ratio, and Price-to-Sales (P/S) ratio with those of other companies in the same industry. - Relative Valuation Method is straightforward to operate, widely used for rapid assessment and comparison within the same industry.
  3. Asset Basis Method: This method determines a company’s value by evaluating its net assets – total assets minus liabilities. The Asset Basis Method is suitable for asset-driven companies such as real estate firms or capital-intensive businesses. Application of Valuation Theories:
  • Investment Decisions: Through valuation, investors can identify undervalued or overvalued assets and develop buy or sell strategies.
  • Corporate Mergers & Acquisitions: In M&A transactions, valuation is key to determining the transaction price and influences the success or failure of the deal.

Valuation Theory

  • Financial Reporting: Companies need to assess the fair value of their assets and liabilities to ensure the accuracy and transparency of financial statements.

Please note that valuation results are influenced by various factors, including market conditions, company operations, macroeconomic indicators, etc. Therefore, when conducting a valuation, it is necessary to consider all factors comprehensively and combine qualitative and quantitative analysis to obtain a more accurate assessment.

item.title: AI Development Over Two Years: Somewhat similar to the state before a Docker release – fragmented and rapidly evolving.
item.description:
Artificial Intelligence (AI) has undoubtedly been one of the most hotly debated topics in the technology field in recent years, particularly over the past two years, with AI technology experiencing rapid advancements. Whether it’s deep learning, natural language processing, or computer vision and automated decision systems, the application scenarios for AI are constantly emerging. However, despite continuous technological breakthroughs, AI still faces a bottleneck similar to that of a Docker release – a lack of a killer app to truly ignite the market.

Prompt: Write an article: AI has developed for two years, which is somewhat like the state of Docker’s pre-release, lacking a killer application, based on existing technologies, create a perfect landing scenario, Docker doesn’t use too many new technologies, but the overall solution is reasonable, and it changes the workflow of operations and development.

AI Development Status: The Technology is Mature, but Applications Still Need Breakthroughs

From a technical perspective, AI has made significant progress in the past two years. Whether it’s OpenAI’s GPT series models or Google’s BERT and DeepMind’s Alpha series, AI processing capabilities have far exceeded previous expectations. Particularly in the field of natural language processing, models like GPT-4 not only possess powerful generative abilities but also demonstrate astonishing performance in understanding and reasoning.

However, despite technological advancements, AI’s implementation in practical applications faces certain challenges. Similar to Docker’s state before its release, although AI has enormous potential, there isn’t yet a killer application that can be widely adopted and transform industries. Everyone is talking about the future of AI, but it may not always be possible to find an application scenario that can directly bring about revolutionary change.

Docker and AI Parallels: Technology Doesn’t Have to Be Innovation, It’s About the Solution

Looking back at the history leading up to Docker’s release, we can readily see many similarities between the technological environment at that time and the current state of AI development. Before Docker, container technology wasn’t a new concept; early technologies like LXC (Linux Containers) and virtualization already possessed the basic capabilities for containerization. However, Docker didn’t introduce disruptive technology itself. Instead, it presented a simpler, more intuitive, and efficient solution through the clever integration and optimization of existing technologies. This solution didn’t bring about revolutionary technology, but it addressed many pain points in operations and development processes, dramatically simplifying software deployment, scaling, and management workflows.

Similarly, the AI field is facing a similar situation. Currently, AI technology is no longer a “new thing,” but to truly achieve large-scale applications, it still requires a perfect landing scenario. Like Docker, integrating and optimizing existing technologies to form a reasonable application solution. A killer AI application may not rely on groundbreaking technological breakthroughs, but rather how to integrate existing technologies to solve pain points and needs in actual business operations.

How to Find AI’s “Docker Moment”?

To truly enable the widespread adoption of AI technology, we need to focus on several key areas:

  1. Deep Exploration of Real-World Scenarios Currently, many AI applications are still primarily experimental in nature and lack large-scale real-world implementation. Areas such as AI customer service and intelligent recommendations are widely used, but their functionality is still limited and has not yet broken through industry bottlenecks. True breakthroughs may come from industries that have been plagued by traditional methods for a long time, such as healthcare, manufacturing, and logistics. AI can help these companies improve efficiency and reduce costs in complex scenarios through more efficient data processing and predictive analytics.

  2. Productization and Ease of Use Similar to how Docker simplifies containerization processes to improve operations efficiency, the ease of use of AI products is equally crucial. AI’s proliferation isn’t just about the spread of technology; it’s also about the proliferation of its products. Integrating AI into daily workflows, allowing users to easily utilize these tools without needing to deeply understand the underlying technology, is a crucial step in AI adoption.

  3. Ecosystem Building & Standardization Any new technology’s widespread application relies on ecosystem building. Docker’s rapid rise is due to its openness and compatibility, enabling developers to seamlessly connect with various cloud platforms, tools, and services. Similarly, AI’s future depends on the construction of an ecosystem. The standardization of AI, model sharing, data openness, and technological integration will all influence whether AI can form widespread industry applications.

Conclusion: The Future of AI is Full of Possibilities, but Requires More Refined Implementation

Despite the significant advancements in AI technology over the past two years, it remains in the stage of “lacking killer applications” at present. Similar to containerization technology before Docker’s release, AI needs a reasonable application scenario to deeply integrate existing technologies with business requirements in order to truly achieve large-scale adoption and widespread use. While technological innovation is important, solutions that can simplify processes and improve efficiency are more likely to drive the popularization and development of the technology.

In the future, AI may evolve like Docker – not through disruptive technological breakthroughs, but by integrating existing technologies to create a perfect application scenario, ultimately changing the way we work and live.

item.title: Golden Week and National Day holiday periods saw the stock market’s “ice and fire dichotomy”: dramatic swings between soaring gains and sharp declines.
item.description:
On the eve of China’s National Day in 2024, the stock market experienced a remarkable surge, attracting considerable attention. However, following the holiday, the market unexpectedly turned to a dramatic plunge. This “polarization” of the stock market – a rollercoaster ride between soaring highs and plummeting lows – not only subjected investors to a thrilling yet nerve-wracking experience, but also prompted deep reflection on policy, economics, and market fundamentals.

[Insert relevant news snippets and data visualizations here - this section would be populated with actual content for a blog post.]

Pre-National Day Stock Surge: A Policy-Driven Frenzy

Over the five trading days leading up to National Day, China’s stock market surged from a slump into “boiling mode.” On September 30th, the A-share market saw a broad rally with all indices hitting historic highs. The Shanghai Composite Index rose by 8.06%, the Shenzhen Component Index increased by 10.67%, and the ChiNext Board Index soared by 15.36%, with the northbound CSI 50 Index setting a record for the largest single-day rise, jumping 22.84%. Market sentiment was extremely exuberant, with daily trading volumes across the Shanghai, Shenzhen, and Beijing Stock Exchanges reaching RMB 2611.5 billion, up RMB 1155.9 billion compared to the previous day. More than 5300 stocks on the main board rallied collectively, creating a “sea of red.”

The driving force behind this rally was the concentrated release of a series of unexpectedly positive policies by the government and the resulting changes in market expectations. On September 24th, the People’s Bank of China announced a cut in the reserve requirement ratio (RRR) and interest rates, reducing the interest rates on existing mortgages, and unified the minimum down payment ratios for mortgages. At the Central Political Bureau meeting on September 26th, it was emphasized that efforts should be made to intensify counter-cyclical fiscal and monetary policy adjustments, strive to boost capital markets, and actively guide medium and long-term funds into investment. On September 30th, a series of ten real estate support policies were released. These policy measures conveyed the government’s firm determination to stabilize the market and promote growth.

Post-National Day Stock Market Plunge: Calm and Adjustment After the Frenzy

However, market sentiment plummeted sharply after the National Day holiday. On October 8th, the A-share market opened strongly with nearly a limit-up rise, but following a significant high opening, the market experienced violent fluctuations before closing down. Since then, the market’s center of gravity has continuously shifted downwards, and as of October 16th, the Shanghai Composite Index rose and fell by more than 15%, cumulatively falling by over 470 points. From October 8th to 10th, core A-share indices all declined, with the Shenzhen Component Index down 6.21%.

The reasons for this plunge are multifaceted, on one hand, digesting the accumulated risks from a rapid rise in the previous period, and on the other hand, related to adjustments in market expectations regarding policy. Some investors believe that the short-term effects of policies have become apparent, but the long-term effects still need to be observed. Furthermore, fluctuations in global markets also impacted A-shares. On October 9th, the Hang Seng Index plummeted by 9.41%, and A50 futures fell by 10.

Reflection and Outlook on the Market

The dramatic volatility in the stock market around National Day highlighted a deep reflection among investors regarding policy, economics, and market fundamentals. On one hand, the short-term stimulus effects of policies were significant, but their long-term impact remains to be observed. On the other hand, the rapid rise and fall of the market served as a reminder for investors to maintain rationality and avoid emotional investment.

Looking ahead, whether A-shares can usher in a genuine “long bull” trend depends on whether policy can effectively transmit to the real economy and ultimately drive substantive improvements in economic fundamentals. Investors should closely monitor the specific implementation of policies and changes in economic data to rationally adjust their investment strategies.

The sharp rallies and crashes in the stock market around National Day were a game between policy and the market, and also a test of investors’ mindset.

item.title: “Making an investment and making money isn’t urgent, and even if you’re anxious, it won’t help.”
item.description:
Reflecting on years of stock trading experiences, although I didn’t make a fortune, I also didn’t lose too much. The biggest issue was an unreasonable allocation of funds and an unstable mindset. Currently, my primary source of income is work, earning a fixed salary each day through part-time jobs. My ability to withstand financial fluctuations remains at the level of bonds and bank deposits. However, people are inherently greedy; if you buy too little, even when prices rise, you won’t make money; if you buy too much, you will lose money. At this point, maintaining a stable mindset is particularly important, as it can help us keep our wealth afloat.

Prompt: Write an article: Addressing the mental issues in stock trading finance.

Historical Loss Cases

Aside from the initial entry into the market, I’ve encountered small-cap and near-new stocks. Later, my investments focused primarily on blue-chip large-cap stocks: Industrial Bank, China Unicom, HK Electronics, ZTESC, and various large index funds.

“Expecting an annualized return while hearing bullish calls about matching a bank’s three-year fixed deposit,” in reality, it was driven by greed wanting more, leading to hasty increases in positions followed by depletion of cash flow. Purchases of insurance, real estate, and weddings represented significant capital outflows, and overall, there wasn’t enough liquidity allocated for these investments, resulting in insufficient funds later on. Buying blue chips is like aligning with “old money”—

  • When Evergrande ran into trouble, bank stocks plummeted dramatically, successfully capitalizing on the opportunity to clear out positions. This reflects a lack of understanding regarding the impact on the broader economy. The real estate sector’s dominance within China’s economic landscape necessitates avoiding a hard landing; consequently, continued stock market declines affected red-chip stocks like Industrial Bank, which rose for about two years.
  • During the initial stages of the trade war, Zhongxing was severely impacted, and its share price also fell sharply. It has since gradually recovered.
  • HSPE (Hubei Hongyu Electronic) is a legacy company; after Ant Group’s departure, its stock price also plummeted significantly. However, this stock benefits from market manipulation by a major shareholder, which allows it to surge several times per year. With reasonable position control, losses can be minimized.

Greed: The “Monster” Devouring Reason

Greed is the most common problem in a stock trading mindset. When stock prices rise steadily, and investors’ account profits continuously increase, greed quietly takes root. Many people still fantasize about continued upward movement of stocks even when they are already at high levels, craving more gains, and refusing to cut their profits. They are blinded by greed, forgetting the existence of market rules and risks. For example, during the hype of certain hot-topic stocks, some investors see a doubling or even several times increase in prices over a short period, and become trapped, constantly adding to their positions, hoping to be the last winner. However, the market will not always go crazy; when the bubble bursts and stock prices plummet sharply, these investors driven by greed often suffer heavy losses.

Fear: The “Chains” That Restrict

Fear is the counterpart to greed. It possesses a powerful destructive force in the stock market as well. When market conditions suddenly reverse and stock prices plummet dramatically, investors are prone to panic. This fear erodes their confidence in the market, even when the fundamentals of their holdings are sound, leading them to hastily sell off their shares out of a fear of further losses. For example, during periods of global financial crises, even high-quality blue-chip stocks saw significant declines alongside the broader market. Some investors were consumed by fear and failed to recognize the long-term value of these companies, selling their stock at extremely low prices and missing out on the substantial returns that came with subsequent market rebounds and company performance growth. Fear not only causes short-term losses for investors but can also create a lasting psychological shadow over the stock market, making them hesitant to re-enter investments and thus losing out on investment opportunities.

Blind Following: Losing Direction in the “Fog”

In stock trading and wealth management, blindly following trends is another psychological pitfall that investors easily fall into. In an era of information overload, various investment suggestions, market rumors, and hot topics are rampant. Many investors lack independent thinking and judgment abilities, blindly following others’ operations. When they see their peers making money by buying a particular stock, they immediately follow suit without further thought; when they hear so-called “insider news,” they readily share it. This blind following behavior ignores the research and analysis of the underlying stocks, causing investors to be like lost ships in the fog, losing their own direction. For example, some momentum stocks can generate short-term gains for followers during the initial market hype. However, as the hype fades and stock prices plummet, those investors who lack understanding and blindly follow become “pickup operators.” They fail to realize that each investor’s risk tolerance, investment objectives, and investment horizon are different; an investment strategy suitable for one person may not be suitable for themselves.

Overconfidence: The Hidden “Rocks”

Overconfidence is also a significant issue in the investment and financial mindset. Some investors, after achieving several successful investments, begin to inflate their egos, believing they have mastered market patterns and can accurately predict stock movements. They ignore the complexity and uncertainty of the market, engage in excessive trading, blindly expand their investment scale, and even use high leverage for speculation. However, the market is ever-changing, and overconfident investors often suffer severe setbacks in a single unexpected market fluctuation. For example, some investors with limited experience who achieved an initial victory believe they possess professional investment capabilities and begin to frequently buy and sell stocks, continuously increasing their investment amount. When systemic risks or sudden negative news about individual stocks emerge, they fail to cut their losses promptly due to overconfidence, leading to a significant reduction in their principal amounts.

How to Adjust Your Mindset for Stable Investing

  • Establish the Right Investment Philosophy: Investors should clearly understand that stock investing and wealth management are aimed at achieving long-term, stable asset appreciation, not overnight riches. By learning investment knowledge, understanding market rules, adopting value investing and long-term investment philosophies, and avoiding being swayed by short-term profits and market sentiment, you can make informed decisions. For example, thoroughly research a company’s fundamentals, paying attention to its profitability, industry position, management team, and other relevant factors, choosing stocks with long-term investment potential rather than blindly chasing short-term trends.
  • Develop a Reasonable Investment Plan: Based on your financial situation, risk tolerance, and investment goals, create a scientific and reasonable investment plan. Clearly define key elements such as the amount to invest, the investment timeframe, expected returns, and stop-loss points, and strictly execute according to the plan. This can help avoid impulsive decisions made due to emotional fluctuations during investment. For example, set the investment proportion of each stock to no more than a certain percentage of total assets, and promptly take profits when the price rises to reach the expected return, and decisively cut losses when it falls to the stop-loss point.

Control emotions and remain calm: When facing market volatility, you need to learn to control your own emotions, maintain calmness and rationality. You can relieve investment pressure by diverting attention, engaging in physical exercise, or communicating with others, avoiding negative impacts of emotion on investment decisions. When the market experiences a significant fluctuation, first calmly analyze the reasons, combine them with your investment strategy and stock fundamentals, and make rational judgments instead of blindly following trends or panic selling.

How to Adjust Your Mindset for Steady Wealth Management

  • Continuous Learning and Reflection: The stock market is constantly evolving, and investors need to continuously learn new investment knowledge and skills, paying attention to macroeconomic trends, industry dynamics, and company information, and constantly improving their investment level. At the same time, it’s important to regularly reflect on your investment behavior, summarize experiences and lessons learned, identify problems in your mindset and decision-making, and promptly adjust and improve them. For example, after each investment, review the entire process, analyze the reasons for success and failure, and think about how to avoid similar mistakes in future investments.

item.title: Spring Festival Blockbuster Movie Ticket Price Mystery: The Difference Between Online and Offline Prices
item.description:
During the Spring Festival, a family of seven or eight people wanted to go see a movie. They originally planned to buy tickets on Taopiaopiao and Maoyan. When they looked at the price, it was 60 yuan. Luckily, they had a cinema recharge card that required them to purchase tickets at the cinema’s front desk. They thought about asking the front desk if there were any discounts, but unexpectedly, the same showtime cost only 35 yuan when purchased at the front desk. The price difference was quite surprising.

The “Hidden Add-on” of Platform Service Fees

While online ticketing platforms are convenient, platform service fees cannot be ignored. They provide users with a seamless booking experience, such as precise seat selection and the ability to view purchase history at any time – all of which require investment in maintenance. These costs are then passed on to consumers through increased ticket prices.

Cinema Differentiation Operation Strategies

With the explosive demand for movie-watching during the Spring Festival, cinemas adopted differentiated pricing strategies to maximize revenue. Online platforms have a large volume of traffic, and many people are accustomed to purchasing tickets online in advance; therefore, cinema ticket prices were set higher on these platforms. Meanwhile, those buying tickets directly at the box office – walk-in customers – received lower prices to attract this segment of the audience.

The Price Logic Behind Revenue Sharing

Revenue sharing models between online platforms and cinemas impact ticket prices. For an online platform to take a slice of the box office revenue – in order to maintain profitability – they will typically raise ticket prices. Conversely, cinema box offices have no intermediary sales process, resulting in lower costs, which naturally leads to more affordable ticket prices.

Consumer Ticket Buying Tips

Don’t just look at online platforms when buying tickets. Call the cinema’s front desk to inquire about prices, or go directly to the front desk and ask – you might find a surprise! If you frequently watch movies, get an auditorium membership card to enjoy member discounts and save money.

item.title: Analysis of Political Elements in 2025 Spring Festival Film Releases
item.description:
It’s been a long time since I went to the Spring Festival movie release to join in the crowds, and this time I watched two films that felt quite different.

This article explores the new changes in the 2025 Spring Festival movie releases, focusing on Dwelling in the Fuchun Pavilion (Tangrenjie Tanjian 1900) and Nezha: The Devil’s Child. The former utilizes the backdrop of San Francisco’s Chinatown in 1900 to depict the discrimination and oppression faced by Chinese people, reflecting social and political conditions. As an animated film, the latter employs rich metaphorical elements to subtly critique the current international political landscape – such as the Jade Palace resembling the Pentagon mirroring the American political system, the dollar symbol on the Heavenly Mandate Throne symbolizing U.S. dollar hegemony, the jade amulet held by the immortals representing green cards and signifying social status, and the Soul-Devouring Elixir akin to biological weapons reflecting malicious actions. Both films offer a new viewing experience and prompt reflection on the relationship between cinematic art and political expression.

Innovation in the Style of Chinese New Year Film Releases

Previously, films released during the Spring Festival often featured lighthearted entertainment and family-friendly themes, aiming to allow audiences to relax and unwind during the holiday season, rarely addressing sensitive political topics. However, in 2025, the Spring Festival release broke with convention; The Mystery Down South 1900 and Nezha: Part One incorporated rich political elements, sparking widespread discussion among viewers and bringing a new atmosphere to the Spring Festival film slate.

“Shanghai Noon 1900”: A Vivid Depiction of Era Politics

“Shanghai Noon 1900” is set in San Francisco’s Chinatown in 1900, a time when Chinese immigrants faced severe racial discrimination and oppression overseas. The protagonists not only have to solve the mystery of the case but also confront discrimination and unfair treatment from all sides of society. The film’s portrayal of racism and power struggles accurately reflects the social and political environment of that tumultuous era, allowing us to see the difficult struggle of Chinese immigrants for survival and dignity, and the underlying political issues worth deep consideration.

Such historical context inevitably reminds us of the challenges currently faced by overseas Chinese in the business sector, such as the TikTok and Zhou Zaikun incident. As of December 6, 2024, the U.S. Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia in Washington, D.C., rejected TikTok’s request, ruling that the congressional law passed under national security grounds requiring a forced sale stood up to constitutional scrutiny. TikTok CEO Zhou Shouheng wrote in a memo to employees that the next step would be “seeking an injunction and awaiting review by the U.S. Supreme Court.” The issue stems from the U.S.’s “Protecting Americans from Foreign Adversary Control of Critical Technology” Act, which mandates that ByteDance must divest its TikTok business within 270 days after passage of the law, with a final deadline of January 19, 2025.

“The Cop Next Door 1900”: A Vivid Depiction of Political Times

Prior to various hearings, Zhou Haosheng also faced numerous difficulties. On January 31, 2024, the U.S. Senate Judiciary Committee held a hearing on “Big Tech and the Crisis of Online Child Sexual Exploitation,” featuring well-known anti-China lawmaker Tom Cotton. Facing Zhou Haosheng, Cotton fired off eight questions regarding his nationality, including asking if he was Chinese, whether he had applied for Chinese or American citizenship, and even probing into the nationalities of his wife and children. Despite the hearing’s focus on “online child sexual exploitation,” the lawmaker shifted the topic to TikTok being owned by a Chinese company, ByteDance, prompting Zhou Haosheng to answer irrelevant questions. “Just as in The Mystery of Chinatown 1900, Chinese people abroad faced unwarranted discrimination, Zhou Shengyi also encountered unfair treatment and scrutiny in the business sector due to his background with TikTok. This series of events reflects how overseas Chinese have consistently faced formidable obstacles when pursuing their own development and safeguarding their rights across different eras – whether it’s racial prejudice a century ago or today’s political manipulation in commerce – warrants deep reflection.”

“The Deer and the Phoenix: Born to Be Wild”: Political Metaphor Behind the Myth Unveiled

“The Deer and the Phoenix: Born to Be Wild” appears to be a typical animated film, but many of its settings and plots are laden with political metaphors.

  • Mapping of Power Systems: The Yuhuang Palace is shaped like the center of supreme power in the celestial realm, with architectural styles similar to the U.S. Pentagon, primarily using white tones symbolizing Western hegemony disguised under the banner of “universal values.” The “Monster Hunting Team” led by Wuliang Xianzun, with its subordinates Lu Ban and He Feifei, are believed to correspond to the US alliance system of Japan and Korea. The Yuhuang Palace’s “online meeting” scene, where twelve golden immortals gather to discuss the “Battle of Opening Heaven,” is like the NATO meetings led by the United States, suppressing other countries under the guise of “maintaining order.” - Subtext of Economic Hegemony: The Yu Huh Palace’s celestial tripod used for alchemy, with dollar signs at the entrance, symbolizes America “refining” other nations’ resources through economic hegemony. The Great Immortals Wu Liangxian, invoking the name of “upholding heaven and earth,” cast the dragons into the cauldron to be refined, much like certain countries exploiting interests under the guise of “international rules.”
  • Metaphor for Identity and Hierarchy: The fairy identity amulet obtained by Nezha, with its color and pattern design resembling an American green card, symbolizes the immortals’ rejection and hierarchical division of “foreign races,” hinting at the differences and unequal treatment between different nations and groups in reality.
  • Hidden Allusions to Malicious Actions: Great Immortals Wu Liangxian forcing Nezha to take the Soul-Destroying Pill, which resembles a bioweapon, darkly alludes to certain countries using the guise of “saving the world” to carry out destructive and ruinous actions against others.

“The Deer and the Phoenix: Born to Be Wild”: A Political Allegory Hidden Behind Mythology – An Analysis

  • Symbol of Resources and Development: The Seven Colored Lotus, as a key to reshaping Niuwa and敖丙’s bodies, symbolizes monopolized energy and technological lifelines dominated by major powers. Its “瓊漿玉液” (琼浆玉液 - literally “jade elixir and pearl liquid”) requires obtaining through the Yuxu Palace’s “成仙考试” (cheng Xian kaoshi – “Celestial Transformation Examination”), reflecting developing countries’ reliance on core resources and suffering from “rule-based plunder” within a hegemonic system. The Lotus’ temporary failure and restoration conditions metaphorically represent the survival dilemmas of small nations in an era of energy crises.

Deep Reflections on Cinematic Art and Political Expression

These films, amidst the nationwide viewing craze during the Spring Festival, incorporated political elements, offering audiences a new cinematic experience – one that moved beyond simple entertainment and served as a mirror reflecting political issues within history and reality. This has prompted us to delve into the relationship between cinematic art and political expression. Will directors in future film creations increasingly convey their perspectives on social and political matters through cinema? As a powerful cultural transmission medium, can film simultaneously engage in artistic expression while also taking greater notice and consideration of societal realities? These questions are worth exploring as we appreciate films, and we look forward to the film industry bringing more exciting integration of art and real-world expression.
